Dwight \"Bucky\" Bleichert.Action: Runs away from the chaotic riot area to a quiet street, trying to gather his thoughts instead of joining in the mob violence or cheering with others.
Runs into a chaotic scene and immediately intervenes to help subdue violent marines by defending the police officer and fighting with his fists.
Runs into a chaotic situation and immediately joins the fight, effectively using his fists and baton to subdue multiple attackers.
Covers the unconscious Tomas Dos Santos with a blanket after he passes out drunk.
Follows Lee's lead calmly during the arrest and helps cover the drunk fugitive with a blanket after he passes out.
Questions the necessity of rousting the fugitive late at night, showing some hesitation.
Watches Tomas Dos Santos die in the gas chamber but cannot stand it and leaves
Refuses to share partnership with Lee, saying 'I'm not your partner'
Smiles thinly in response to a rookie cop's shadow punching and joking interactions.
Engages in casual banter with fellow officer Tom Joslin, showing some social connection.
Dismissing gossip and jokes about promotion, showing emotional reservation.
Shakes hands and nods respectfully to Chief Green, Lee Blanchard, and DA Ellis Loew upon introduction.
Maintains awkward silence in the office, showing possible discomfort or reservation.
Reads the note aloud with some hesitation but cooperates fully with authority figures.
Hits the speed-bag intensely, showing personal discipline and physical preparation.
Called into Chief of Detectives office along with other high-ranking officials, indicating trust and recognition.
Reads aloud a newspaper passage highlighting his past distinction in the '43 Zoot Suit Wars, reflecting recognized past competence.
Agrees to participate in charity boxing match to help raise morale and support police department funding.
Responds to Lee's challenge with good-natured acceptance despite teasing about lasting rounds.
Responds with 'Uh, yes sir' to Loew’s remark about potentially becoming colleagues, showing respectful politeness.
Delivers a public speech supporting a bond proposal with appropriate references and subtlety, showing thoughtful presentation skills.
Makes a quick, confident decision to accept the boxing match challenge despite being aware of his odds, demonstrating decisiveness and confidence.
Briefly assesses Lee's physicality before agreeing to the fight, showing situational awareness and strategic thinking.
Shares a friendly, teasing exchange with Lee and Kay, including shaking hands and laughing.
Does not respond to Kay calling him by his real name, despite noticing it.
Confidently engages in banter and negotiations about the stakes of a fight, showing understanding of the situation and keeping composure.
Conceals emotional reaction to Kay Lake using his real name, demonstrating self-control and awareness of social dynamics.
Carries a box full of canned goods and old magazines to visit his destitute father, tries to engage him despite father's hostility and squalor.
Expresses disgust and sadness facing his father's condition but still sits next to him and attempts communication.
Trains rigorously by hitting the heavy bag, running with weights on ankles, and sparring effectively with a fighter, showing discipline and physical skill.
Maintains composure and control in a difficult emotional situation when facing his father’s physical and mental decay without lashing out or losing focus.
Carries old girlie magazines and canned goods to his father’s house, showing a responsible and caring attitude but perhaps also an inability to confront problems beyond basic provision.
Fails to emotionally engage or escalate confrontation with his father despite obvious provocation, possibly demonstrating restraint or passivity.
Calls to arrange care and cleaning for his father after stroke, promises to pay and keep time limit.
Watches Lee spar attentively, analyzing performance with respect.
Engages in discreet financial exchange related to boxing bets, showing guardedness and pragmatic attitude.
Arranges care for his father after a stroke, shows responsibility and initiative.
Observes Lee sparring carefully, mentally preparing by simulating the fight.
Successfully obtains a significant amount of cash by filling out proper forms at a bank.
Places a confident, calculated bet on a boxing match with knowledge of the odds and opponent's style.
Takes Pete's handshake and exchanges greetings.
Watches his father from across the street as someone tries to feed him, showing some concern.
Reflects bitterly on his father but also considers securing his care via ill-gotten money.
Carefully analyzes Lee's fighting style with keen observation.
Receives a friendly, teasing comment from Kay and engages in light conversation.
Engages in light, playful banter with Kay, showing a relaxed and friendly interaction.
Persists in asking Kay a personal question despite her avoidance, showing some impatience or pushiness.
Reflects alone in his apartment, appearing restless and contemplative about Kay’s comment, indicating sincerity and emotional openness.
Persistently puzzles over Kay's cryptic statements, showing dedication to understanding situations.
Proactively obtains and reviews newspaper clippings in the morgue late at night to investigate.
Lingers on personal distractions (Kay's comments) late into the night, indicating restlessness but possibly affecting focus.
Passes a prostitute on the street and briefly makes eye contact before walking on.
Walks through downtown L.A., hands stuffed in pockets, showing a casual, somewhat confident demeanour like James Dean.
No direct active involvement or initiative shown in the excerpt; mainly walking passively and observing without engaging.
Looks back to give the whore a second look but she’s gone.
Refuses to answer the phone despite repeated ringing while recovering from his fight injuries.
Surreptitiously watches his father struggling to grab at a nurse in a rest home.
Stands silently and watches his father struggle in the rest home hallway.
Acknowledges Lee Blanchard’s invitation to work warrants, displays openness to reconnect and engage.
Accepts standing ovation from fellow officers modestly, no boastfulness shown.
Surreptitiously watches his father in the rest home, showing awareness and caution.
Confidently clips at his stitches by himself, showing self-reliance and steadiness.
Expresses hesitation and low confidence ('But I lost. Loew’s deal--'), revealing some vulnerability or doubt about his effectiveness.
Responds positively to Lee’s invite to return to work, indicating willingness and readiness to re-engage professionally.
Receives a standing ovation from fellow officers, indicating peer recognition and respect.
Smiles a dumb smile, not knowing what to say when greeted by new colleagues.
Bucky listens attentively during the meeting, taking in his new surroundings and tuning back in to the captain's summary.
Smiles a dumb smile when introduced by Russ Millard, not knowing what to say.
Bucky smiles a dumb smile, not knowing what to say when introduced; does not assert himself aggressively.
Responds politely with 'The proposition passed, sir' when Ellis Loew reproaches him but does not argue back.
Allows Lee to take the lead and be the primary speaker in tense situations, deferring social dominance.
Slugged with opponent despite being ahead, ignoring advice to play smarter, risking professional standing.
Acknowledges proposition passed and tries to defend his action, shows some confidence in decisions.
Works with Lee to follow investigative leads, shows ability to adapt and cooperate during police work.
Follows Lee’s lead into restaurant to confront suspect, indicating trust in process but not taking full initiative.
Follows a suspect discreetly to avoid alarming him, shows patience and caution.
Pulls gun and arrests Maynard Coleman quickly and firmly to protect children nearby.
Identifies the target (Coleman) quickly and suggests where to park to follow him.
Follows Coleman discreetly and observes his movements carefully at the ice skating rink.
Responds promptly to Lee’s gesture to stop using the radio, showing tactical awareness.
Surprises Coleman by pulling his gun and arresting him as he walks upstairs, displaying decisiveness and control.
Does not react negatively or lose control when a small boy interferes by pounding on his leg.
Continues marching Coleman the elder up the stairs despite the child's hysterics, both father and son crying.
Acknowledges Lee's instruction to 'play nice' but makes a sarcastic comment 'Play nice. Hm.' about Koenig and Vogel.
Calmly manages a tense situation by escorting Coleman and handling the hysterical boy, maintaining control and focus.
Observes and internally notes the behavior and attitudes of colleagues and superiors, showing situational awareness and critical thinking.
No indication of stepping up to confront tension or conflict with Koenig and Vogel despite their dismissive attitude toward him.
Engages warmly with Lee and Kay, shares laughter and makes a toast including all present, showing inclusiveness and friendliness.
Jokes about Lee taking bribes in a familiar, teasing manner, indicating friendly rapport.
Impressed by Lee's house and joking about bribes shows social awareness and situational understanding.
Checks around the dining room and observes dynamics, indicating attentiveness and situational awareness.
Engages in light-hearted banter and toasts, showing confidence and ease in social settings.
Becomes abruptly drunk and a bit less guarded in his toast, which might suggest a temporary lapse in control or professionalism.
Looks disgusted at corrupt or questionable politics.
Expresses skepticism and disgust about corrupt or political maneuvers, showing awareness and critical thinking.
Listens attentively and engages with Ellis Loew and his team regarding Raymond Nash's crimes, showing professional focus and collaborative behavior.
Accepts information on a volatile suspect and violent crime calmly, indicating a capacity to handle stressful cases with measured responses.
After shifts, spends time with Kay and Lee; joins for dinners, dancing, and movies, valuing companionship.
Follows Lee’s lead on a potentially racially tense police stop without hesitation or expressed concern.
Successfully captures eleven hard felons, eighteen traffic warrantees, and three parole and probation absconders during a period of months with Lee.
Displays awareness of neighborhood racial dynamics by noting 'It's all colored down there' before proceeding with Lee's plan.
Follows Lee's lead unquestioningly when Lee says 'We fuckin' roll' despite Bucky's voiced concern about the area.
Warns Lee by shouting 'Partner!' when he sees a threat, showing concern for his partner's safety.
After the shooting, he vomits in the gutter, indicating emotional distress and sensitivity to violence.
Pins his badge to his jacket pocket immediately after the shooting, maintaining professionalism despite personal turmoil.
Calmly explains to the detective that Lee was emotionally affected because he knew one of the gunmen, showing empathy and awareness of others' feelings.
Notices the black man reaching for a weapon and warns his partner, then accurately shoots multiple attackers to neutralize threats.
Hits the ground on partner’s warning, demonstrating quick reflexes and situational awareness.
Stumbles and vomits after the shootout, showing physical weakness or inability to immediately recover from trauma.
Maintains composure and professionalism at the detectives' station despite looking worn.
Does not display overt emotional breakdown like his partner Lee, indicating mental resilience and steadiness.
Understands the threat posed by Bobby DeWitt and shows confidence in handling it by assuring Kay 'We can take care of Bobby DeWitt.'
Acknowledges the danger but also shows some hesitation or uncertainty by not immediately taking decisive action and simply reading the newspaper while others are distressed.
Withdraws and appears fidgety and unsure about leaving Lee and Kay's house, indicating discomfort and inability to fully assert control or decisiveness in the situation.
Bucky backs away, choking back tears after seeing Kay's scars.
Answers Lee's call with concern, asks if he is okay.
Joins Lee to investigate a possible crime scene promptly and seriously.
Recognizes a developing crime scene quickly and acts promptly by noticing the officers and coroner's van, then moves with Lee to investigate the scene.
Does not find immediate evidence in the initial search and shows no visible frustration or rash action, indicating measured and patient behavior.
Retreats emotionally when confronted by Kay's scars, choking back tears rather than maintaining professional detachment.
Shows concern for proper procedure by informing Russ Millard about Nash renting a room nearby and assuring no blood on premises
Unable to stop staring at the mutilated body, indicating emotional impact
Engages politely and cooperatively with various community members while questioning them about the case.
Expresses irritation at being stood up for the boxing match and leaves the empty seat.
Shows frustration with Lee for prioritizing the case over their personal plans, indicating some tension but also concern.
Questions multiple potential witnesses systematically during door-to-door inquiries in Leimert Park.
Engages in conversation with Lee about priorities, showing awareness of police politics and operational dynamics.
Leaves the boxing match early in irritation, demonstrating possible lack of focus or discipline.
Expresses concern and disbelief at the corrupt handling of the case, shows disgust at press conference.
Shakes head and walks away after Lee insists on carrying on without him.
Relents to Lee’s reasoning after study and shows some trust in Lee’s judgment.
Silently endures grim autopsy scene without visible emotional reaction or comfort toward others present.
Studies Lee's resolve carefully and initially resists before relenting, showing deliberation.
Feels skeptical about Lee's reasoning but chooses to trust it temporarily, indicating careful but flexible judgment.
Participates in the autopsy observation with other officers, paying attention to details regarding the victim's condition.
Attentively reviews evidence and follows the flow of the investigation alongside colleagues, showing engagement and professionalism.
Does not speak up during the coroner's report even when technical details or questions arise, possibly indicating passivity or reluctance to contribute expert insight.
Approaches Cleo Short calmly and professionally, introducing himself sincerely.
Appears calm and professional while interviewing a potentially hostile suspect, indicating a measured approach and confidence in police procedure.
Relies on second-in-command Russ Millard's judgment about investigative assignments rather than asserting own ideas, suggesting possible deference or lack of leadership initiative.
Shows patience and restraint by calmly managing Lee's frustration and signaling him to take a walk instead of confronting Cleo Short aggressively.
Asks Cleo Short gentle, clarifying questions about his daughter and the soldier, indicating a respectful and sincere attempt to understand.
Maintains professional composure despite the cruel and dismissive attitude of Cleo Short toward his deceased daughter, not openly challenging the harshness.
Agrees to check on Kay because she is worried about Lee, showing concern for others' feelings.
Responds to Kay's gentle kiss on the cheek with quiet appreciation, indicating warmth and receptiveness.
Keeps to himself quietly at the table, eating a simple meal and working on reports, showing discipline but little overt sociability.
Suggests flipping through the reports to see who wrote it up, indicating awareness and proactive thinking about the case.
Agrees to check on Kay because she is worried about Lee, showing social awareness and responsibility.
Recognizes and appreciates Kay's subtext about Lee's behavior, showing perceptiveness.
Sits down calmly to eat and complete police reports, demonstrating steadiness and diligence.
Responds politely to Russ Millard and expresses clear communication, showing respect.
Prefers to try talking first rather than resorting to force with Koenig.
Shows slight frustration or reluctance when assigned to the Black Dahlia case ('I think I want to go back to Warrants').
Shows willingness to cooperate with his superior and accepts assignment to Homicide despite personal preference to return to Warrants.
Checks names against the list carefully before approaching the apartment door.
Decides to attempt a 'talk job' before resorting to a 'muscle job', showing measured judgment and restraint.
Displays no hesitation or confusion when receiving task instructions or interacting with colleagues.
Politely knocks and identifies himself as police before questioning Sheryl.
Uses a mild threat to get Sheryl to talk (reefer flushing), but does so without escalating tension.
Listens attentively and maintains a conversational tone with Sheryl despite her defensiveness.
Dismisses Sheryl's sarcastic or defensive comments without reacting negatively.
Abruptly changes subject when Sheryl reveals sensitive info, perhaps showing some tact.
Uses a subtle threat (reefer flushing) to gain cooperation and get the witness to answer questions.
Maintains focus on the interrogation, quickly changes subject when discussion hits a dead end.
Acknowledges information about the victim moving frequently and tries to explore potential threats, showing investigative intuition.
Offers to handle two men on the stoop himself instead of letting Koenig (Sarge) do it, indicating a willingness to take responsibility.
Merely shakes his head when Koenig runs outside instead of encouraging or directing, showing passive tolerance but no active intervention.
Asks Marjorie about Betty's involvement in movies, showing interest in Betty's background with polite and neutral curiosity.
Encourages Marjorie to share information gently and patiently ('What is it? You can tell me.')
Listens carefully and follows up thoughtfully ('Linda Martin's room?')
Takes Bill Koenig’s information seriously and manages the investigation process ('Take their statements, Bill. I've got a little more here.')
Presses Marjorie for more information about the older woman and the connection to Linda Martin, showing focus and follow-up on leads.
Acts decisively by entering Linda Martin's room, systematically checking the closet and under the bed, and finds a critical piece of evidence (the red vinyl purse with the ID).
Recognizes the significance of the ID he finds and shares it with Marjorie, demonstrating situational awareness and communication.
Does not immediately act on Bill Koenig’s crude report but instructs him to take the statements while continuing his own investigation, showing judgment and ability to delegate.
Reassures Marjorie she couldn't have known calling the police was wrong.
Expresses sarcastic dismissal of Koenig's statement 'No shit Sherlock'.
Omits Marjorie Graham's lead on Lorna Martikova from official report to avoid it being quashed.
Decides to 'kiss off' the rest of the day after feeling overloaded by Betty Short's story.
Issues an APB on Lorna Martikova using his police prerogative and writes up a report while deliberately omitting a lead he deems unhelpful to avoid interference from higher-ups.
Dismisses Koenig's statement sarcastically but does not contradict or correct him, suggesting awareness of the situation's reality.
Decides to stop investigating leads he finds unproductive and takes time off for personal matters, indicating possible burnout or disengagement.
Quietly observes Lee and Kay discussing the case, does not interrupt or assert himself but catches Kay's eye as he leaves.
Decides to visit Lee and Kay to have a sandwich despite feeling emotionally overwhelmed by the case.
Cruises by the crime scene where onlookers gawk and vendors sell cheap souvenirs, indicating detachment or passive observation without interference or empathy.
Pulls up at Lee and Kay's house and quietly observes their discussion of the crime scene photos without interrupting, showing restraint and situational awareness.
Leaves the conversation after Kay proposes a theory, catching her eye, suggesting a subtle but confident communication style.
Cruises past the crime scene later, taking in the atmosphere rather than immediately acting, indicating patience and deliberate consideration.
Sits at his desk staring at Raymond Nash's mugshot late at night, showing focus and commitment to his work.
Removes a mugshot from view, indicating sensitivity or respect toward Raymond Nash.
Approaches a bartender in a lesbian bar respectfully and straightforwardly asks questions about the Dahlia and Linda Martin.
Acknowledges the bartender's warning about underaged involvement and responds appropriately.
Discreetly hides Raymond Nash's mugshot in his desk drawer instead of openly displaying it.
Uses direct street-level investigation by visiting bars to gather information about the Dahlia case.
Engages bartenders and patrons with pertinent questions, showing interpersonal skills and knowledge of the environment.
Downs whiskey quickly, perhaps to gain rapport or blend in with bar crowd.
Does not reveal much information about himself or the investigation, maintaining operational security.
Passes Dahlia's photos around the bar but encounters only raised eyebrows and no leads.
Carefully observes women’s reactions to photos, seeking clues but does not jump to conclusions.
Uses intimidation tactics on bartender to extract information, demonstrating assertiveness and knowledge of consequences.
Remains calm, takes a deep breath and counts to ten before pursuing a suspicious woman, showing self-control and tactical patience.

Quietly tracks the woman connected to the case, notes details carefully without confrontation.
Lies in bed staring at the Black Dahlia's photo, showing persistent concern.
Takes initiative to find tangible leads by recording license plate and following her movements.

Observes interrogation attentively and comments to partner with a confident, light-hearted remark
Engages in casual banter with Lee, remains observant but does not intervene in intense interrogation.

Canvasses the district diligently, talking to many people to get information.
Mentions that barflies and day drinkers offer false or exaggerated accounts to appear glamorous.
Identifies potential evidence suppression by his boss and brings it up despite risk, showing insight and courage.
Successfully canvasses multiple locations and interviews many people to gather information.
Recognizes that much of the witness information is unreliable and plans his report accordingly.
Recognizes overreach and attempts to reason with Lee and Kay about pulling misdemeanors; sets a clear deadline to limit investigation time.
Stops himself mid-argument, showing self-awareness and an ability to reassess the situation before escalating conflict.
Allows Kay to call him gutless and withdraws from confrontation, showing hesitance and possible lack of assertiveness.
Maintains covert surveillance from his car and promptly intercepts Madeleine Sprague, demonstrating patience, observation skills, and quick action when opportunity arises.
Returns money to Madeleine after she offers it, maintaining professional boundaries.
Immediately recognizes Madeleine's dropped bravado and calmly takes her purse and keys to prevent evasion, showing control and concern.
Directly questions Madeleine about her relationship to the victims, showing focus but also a straightforward and sincere approach.
Uses a light teasing tone by asking 'Are you lez?' but remains respectful and engaged.
Recognizes immediately when Madeleine's bravado drops and responds by taking control of the situation (grabs her purse and keys to prevent escape).
Uses direct and pointed questioning to get to the truth, showing sharp interrogation skills.
Maintains focus and professionalism despite being charmed by Madeleine.
Returns over hundred dollars given by Madeleine, possibly to avoid ethical compromise or bribery.
Engages Madeleine in dialogue with some light banter, acknowledges her alibi without overt judgment.
Responds to Madeleine's hint of a bribe with a principled refusal ('I don't need your cash'), indicating integrity.
Knows and remembers Madeleine's address, implying vigilance or perhaps a hint of suspicion rather than warmth.
Engages Madeleine in questioning, remains focused on gathering alibi information despite distractions.
Keeps cool and confident when Madeleine makes a veiled proposition, not immediately giving in.
Accepts meeting Madeleine later but implies awareness and control over situation by stating he knows the address already.
Does not let personal attraction or Madeleine's advances cloud his professional judgment of taking her alibi seriously.
Slides into chair across from Lee, engages in casual conversation about Lee's efforts to smooth things with Kay and suggesting ways to lean on De Witt.
Listens attentively on phone calls, takes notes diligently during tip calls.
Takes diligent notes during police calls, engages in investigative phone duty with focus and patience.
Sits brushing imaginary dust off the phone, suggesting possible distraction or disengagement momentarily.

Keeps track of numerous phone tips and routing slips, showing effort and diligence in gathering information.

Engages intimately with Madeleine, appears emotionally involved, showing vulnerability.

Accepts a provocative caricature of himself from Martha without visible reaction.

Engages in conversation about complex family and criminal backgrounds without losing composure.

Pursues Linda Martin aggressively and manages to detain her despite risks.
Shows situational awareness by picking up and inspecting the purse, discovering the film can.
Interrogates Linda carefully, asking pointed questions that elicit relevant information.
Does not lose control during a chaotic pursuit and arrest situation.

Asks detailed, pointed questions to Linda to clarify facts and motivate her to reveal information.

Expresses uncertainty and acknowledges the solid parts of the story despite doubts, demonstrating balanced judgment.
Demonstrates awareness and intelligence by sarcastically responding to Russ Millard's comment ('a very bright penny today'), indicating mental sharpness in a tense, uncomfortable situation.

Passively watches the screening of a disturbing film involving Betty Short without intervening or reacting strongly, indicating possible emotional detachment or uncertainty how to respond in a difficult context.
Pries the De Witt article from Lee's clenched fist, showing awareness and control of the situation.
Calmly responds to Lee's emotional outburst with empathy and steadiness.
Holds up newspaper to counter Ellis Loew, attempting to assert perspective despite Loew's reprimand.
Invites Madeleine to get together despite her restrictions, showing consideration.
Shares personal, sensitive information with Madeleine and admits to withholding evidence for her.
Appears lost in thought and emotionally troubled while with Madeleine, not engaging warmly in the moment.
Acknowledges his superior's instruction promptly and agrees to act (calls the phone to arrange meeting), showing responsiveness and basic procedural compliance.
Spends morning 'skating around' instead of aggressively pursuing leads, implying some lack of focus or initiative.
Shows knowledge of details in the case (discussing Linda Martin's arrest and evidence in the Dahlia files), indicating investigative awareness.
Confesses to withholding evidence for personal reasons, demonstrating compromised objectivity and questionable judgment.
Is lost in thought during intimate moment, suggesting mental preoccupation or distraction that could affect focus on work.
Leaves Madeleine abruptly after a tense interaction, refusing to stay despite her pleading.
Stares somberly at the murder scene of the Korean shopowner and his son, showing emotional reaction.
Responds with uncontrolled violence by brutally beating up his friend Lee after the tragic incident.
Looks ashamed after beating up Lee, showing remorse.
Comforts Kay by stroking her hair and offers to stay with her if Lee doesn't show up.
Acknowledges serious troubles involving Lee and tries to support Kay emotionally.
Fights Lee aggressively and wins rematch despite injuries.
Feels ashamed about consequences of beating Lee, showing some emotional burden.
Plans to check on Lee and stay with Kay if Lee doesn't show up, showing responsibility and foresight.
Appears disturbed after phone call about investigation, uncertain how to proceed next.
Responds calmly to tense situations, shares relevant information clearly with superiors.
Badges the desk clerk to get a hotel room, quietly asserts authority without conflict.
Charges the DA aggressively but is physically pushed away by others, does not escalate further.
Effectively gathers and follows up on intelligence about Blanchard's whereabouts, acting on parole information and heading to Tijuana to investigate.
Badges the desk clerk and secures a room number without delay, showing confidence and procedural knowledge in a foreign environment.
Interrupts a meeting of higher-ups with key information about Lee and Bobby De Witt, demonstrating initiative and situational awareness.

Is roughly pushed back and denied further action by superiors (Vogel and Koenig), which may indicate limits on his authority or ability to follow through—an external competence boundary rather than a personal failure.
Tosses handfuls of coins to beggar children in Tijuana, causing them to scatter and squabble over money.

Receives praise for being a good detective, suggesting reliability and dedication.
Approaches Russ Millard directly to discuss his transfer status, showing initiative and confidence.

Inability or unwillingness to meet Madeleine Sprague's eyes after their intimate encounter, potentially indicating emotional distraction or lack of control.

Rings Fritz Vogel's doorbell and accepts invitation into his home, showing openness and willingness to engage socially.
Drinks cautiously with others, showing discomfort or mistrust about the situation.
Appears impatient during Ellis Loew's meeting, indicating possible intolerance or frustration.

Methodically reviews rap sheets and mug shots of dangerous men while transporting them, preparing himself mentally for the task.
Grabs the meathook above an old man with palsy to steady him before questioning.
Studies the men's apprehensive faces carefully before proceeding, shows situational awareness by noticing the sheet-covered table out of direct view.
Calmly steadies an old man with palsy by grabbing the meathook to help him focus, demonstrating empathy and control under tense circumstances.
Takes the lead in questioning a suspect methodically, indicating confidence and initiative in a high-pressure environment.
Knows the interrogation is getting out of control and seems disturbed by the violence.
Stares at the fire alarm instead of intervening in the abuse.
Knows the interrogation is getting out of control and is mesmerized/distanced by the fire alarm instead of intervening or taking control.
Hands a quarter to a drunk and urges him to crawl back into a bar using his nightstick.
Keeps his feelings private, turns away from Madeleine after she says she looks like the victim.
Sleeps closely and safely spooning Kay, showing intimacy and trust.
Stares hard, with blazing eyes, at Betty Short during her scream in a violent dream, reflecting internal torment but not acting.
Hands a quarter to a drunk and uses his nightstick to urge him back to a bar, showing control and awareness of maintaining order.
Sits with feet up on bed, flipping through a folder passively while others actively pore over files, indicating disengagement or lack of active contribution.
Remembers Madeleine's words and shows emotional distance by leaving when she says 'You'll be back', then seeks comfort sleeping safely with Kay.
Has a vivid, emotionally charged dream involving violence and the victim, indicating internal conflict but also awareness of the stakes.

Rifles through Fritzie's files looking for truth, shows determination to uncover corruption and protect justice.
Bops to jazz on radio, exhibiting casual, relatable behavior despite tension.

Expresses impatience but is advised to be patient and listens.

Shows concern and patience during Sally's distress, giving her time to speak.

Leans in with Russ Millard to try to get information from Johnny, indicating engagement and presence during the interrogation.
Receiving a derogatory assessment from Daddy, calling him jelly and weak, which suggests lack of confidence from others in his abilities.
Salutes respectfully to Lieutenant Jastrow and carries himself firmly despite difficult news and hostile looks from peers.
Faces accusations and hostile peers with defiant eye contact, not showing weakness.
Appears unsure and passive when questioning his reassignment ('Why?').

Hands out pennies and nickels to locals while flashing his badge and photos, demonstrating generosity and goodwill.

Acknowledges the dangerous environment but remains composed and professional.

Presents photo of missing man professionally to the police chief and attempts to elicit information.

Moves cautiously through an unfamiliar environment, looking deliberately for a person with authority in the club.

Carefully assesses the situation by questioning Dolphine about Vasquez and the risk to himself.

Watches Kay's house quietly, wishes time would stand still or go back

Withdrawn and focused on meticulous, boring lab work, showing no interaction or warmth towards others in his environment.
Meticulously processing blood samples in scientific investigation detail, competently handling routine forensic tasks like collecting latent fingerprints.
Nonchalantly gives another detective fingerprints promptly, indicating reliable and timely workflow.
Despite being relegated to a tedious and low-status role within the LAPD, he continues performing his duties without complaint.
Attempts to hide panic when Kay mentions the loose floorboard, suggesting occasional lapses in composure or confidence in personal matters.
Quickly agrees to fix a household issue when asked, showing willingness and confidence to act practically.

Patiently and respectfully follows Mrs. Chambers into the house, showing deference.
Removes focus from disturbing imagery and redirects attention to family photos, indicating sensitivity.

Questions Kay persistently and tries to get concrete information about the driver involved in the bank job, showing active engagement and determination.

Engages in lighthearted, friendly banter with Jane Chambers in her garden.

Reciprocates Jane's warm handshake and expresses mutual condolence.
Stays silent and does not engage in Jane’s derogatory gossip.
Spies voyeuristically on the Sprague house, watching Madeleine from his car shadows.
Watches Madeleine closely with a mix of fascination and confusion, follows her movements but does not confront her or interrupt her interaction with others.

Parks at a distance to surveil Madeleine without being seen.
Ducks into a crowded bar to observe Madeleine incognito and signals for a drink while remaining alert.

Sprints and apprehends a fleeing suspect by yanking him off a fence and slamming him down.
Sits silently and penitent when reprimanded, showing possible acceptance of fault but potentially lack of assertiveness or confidence.

Engages in casual, somewhat flippant banter about complicated family dynamics without apparent emotional insight or deeper analysis.

Recognizes and catalogs missing items and signs of change in his home.
Stands alone in the slums in uniform, a visible beacon despite personal risk.

Softens for the first time in conversation, leans forward, appearing almost like a father who'd lost a daughter.

Shrugs off talk about his father, showing emotional guardedness or reluctance to share personal feelings.

Softens emotionally, appearing almost vulnerable and fatherly, risking losing professional detachment.
Maintains focus on the investigation despite personal feelings and Cleo's provocation.
Shrugs off talk of his father indicating reluctance or avoidance to engage in potentially important personal backstory that might affect his investigation or self-awareness.
Responds simply and directly about his mother’s suicide without elaboration or emotional expression.

Does not engage in Cleo's antagonistic or sarcastic remarks, instead handles the situation with quiet acceptance.
Gets distracted and nearly causes an accident, indicating internal preoccupation and emotional distance from present surroundings.

Appears confident and in control during a tense situation.

Mentally acknowledges his own rage and violent impulses towards a suspect.
Forcefully demands to see the grave of George Tilden by putting a silenced gun so close to Emmett Sprague's head, demonstrating boldness and control in a tense situation.
Momentarily considers Emmett Sprague's comment about art but shoves the thought aside to focus on the task at hand, showing mental discipline and priority management.
Reflects internally that he'd been confident in identifying George Tilden based on investigation and reasoning, showing awareness of his investigative skills.
Considers the possibility of escalating violence (using a gun) but ultimately restrains himself at this moment, indicating a controlled and calculated approach.
Kicks the tin door shut, sealing the fire inside Elizabeth Short's private hell.
Covers awkwardly when Jane Chambers comments on his repeated staking out of the Sprague house.
Steps back in discomfort at the sight of the clown painting but quickly composes himself and focuses on Jane Chambers, showing attentiveness and restraint.

Surprised to find the front door unlocked but proceeds cautiously with gun drawn, showing a careful and respectful approach to a potentially dangerous situation.
